element_texts.text: Completed

Dear Sherwood:
It was mighty good to see your old "handwrite" again. Hadnt heard from you so long that I wondered if you had moved again. I wrote you about the first of Dec.
Life has been a whirlwind of business for me in the last three months. In this place the urge is so strong and persistent all around one, that it is hard to keep from being sucked in for every atom of thought energy and resource that one can muster. You know my failing. I am like to lose all that I gained in eighteen months of loafing in the little agency that wrecked my "business"-- or where I wrecked it. I have fleeting inspirations of the things I could do -- but when I yield to them I find myself mooning around, and by way of getting into trouble. With me there is no doubt that art and commerce have nothing in common -- or as the old Bible puts it 'Ye cannot serve God and Mammon.'
I am mightlly interested in what you are doing. Told Marco about your forthcoming story with "The Oaks" at Springfield O as a setting, and he pretended to get nervous. Wondered how he would figure in it. You recall that he and the first Mrs. Morrow spent the first years of their married life there. I think you were at the Oaks at that time.
Completed

Those were the ideal days of all his married life He is here today (Sunday) on the other side of the office "in conference" with the farm press manager Marco - another artist gone wrong. We ought to be shot at sunrise -- a beautiful (not a silly chromo of a sunrise) -- wheron we should look at the last moment to realize what fools we have been.
Dick and Ida are with him on this trip. First time I have seen Dick since the accident. He seems to be coming out of it all right. Drags one foot a little, and is nervous. But he seems to be all okay mentally, and has picked up flesh. Nothing short of a miracle the way he was grabbed at the edge of the grave.
Only a snatch of work at my second story now and then -- God -- how I wish you were here to get your angle on some things of which I have been a close spectator. The best yarns of life are not often spun in books
I got "Arlie Gelston" and "Cane." Have just finished Sergel's book. His "psyching" of his characters is fascinating -- particularly of that Gelston girl. There are fine moments -- but for me, he outdoes Sinclair Lewis in his meticulous photography. I think it worth while to plunge into the thoughts of people to follow up all channels even the muddy ones -- but I'm damned if I
Completed

can see anything in photographs of the details of a nasty woman's bad disgusting way of eating or the details of the moving picture business. Or of a booze party. Of course Sergel is young -- and photography is one of the first appeals to the young artist, without a background or storehouse of experience and contacts. Still I think Sergel reveals much promise.
By the way you'd get a laugh out of the fate story of another Iowan really writing of Iowa Do you recall "Red Bud Women" by O'Dea a copy-writer of Lord & Thomas? He wondered if you would write the "blurb" for the cover. Well the transient "notice" that the book got him went to his head like moonshine. It took the form of society aspirations. Lord & Thomas stationed him in New York, and he has become a passionate climber. Told some friends of mine about getting his daughter into an exclusive school "And my dear--you cant image how that has helped us." Incidentally he's by way of climbing himself out of a comfortable salary with L & T--and he hasn't written enough ensure him an income for climbing or even the well known grocery bill
It has been touch and go with the friends we both
Completed

know. Got knocked out of a lunch with T recently by the rude interception of Capper business. Seemed to be the same old T when I met her.
Had a Christmas note from Cornelia. We'll get together for lunch or dinner when she comes to town.
Margie Curry is press agenting for the picture frame manufacturers, and managed to get an article in our magazine if high priced advertising space
Saw Hanly Bohon in Harrodsburg a week ago. Hanly much interested in you. I sent him a copy of "Horses & Men" 
Pete and Papa Steele always ask about you I'm still writing their copy. Pete who doesn't drink a drop nor smoke, and who is an active member of the Baptist church (member of the building committee) slipped me a bottle of Kentucky booze with the hope that you and I would get together Christmas and have a few on him. I had to drink up your share -- and got into trouble. But that's another story.
Was much interested in the travels of Adeline. Have seen references to her in the news of literary lights.
Keep me advised of your address. Ill always write.
Affectionately
Daugherty
Completed

Dear Sherwood:
The third novel is spinning along. I have just finished the ninth chapter, totaling so far about 20,000 words. It is becoming absorbing to me though as you said I have tackled a job. The underlying philosophy is the play of woman's instinct against man's logic. For this purpose I posed a little country girl from Iowa against the manager of a knit underwear factory in Wisconsin. Both are naive, unsophisticated, giving full play for the obvious impulses in the love affair. Eve Watson is getting to be a nice character. It is a modern story, psychological, analytical, with the industry only as an incidental background. I am going to make an effort to market it -- and for this reason am pushing it as as fast as I can.
The second story the old Minneapolis druggist and his fairy stories. I think is in the hands of Brandt Brand. A man in New York who knows Edna Kenton (I had met her in the old South Side days, but I doubt that she remembers me) this man was to undertake to get her to read it -- but I haven't heard whether she has read it or not. I had Macmillan turned it down with this criticism "The book starts off as one thing and ends as another. It ceases to be a novel and becomes a series of throwbacks, and there was not sufficient substance in the fairy tales. In other words the book began solidly and ends but ended too vaguely"
Completed

2
Well-of course I dont know. Is it a criticism that a book ceases to be a novel? The fairy stories it seemed to me were a vital part of Old Ves Walmsleys character. However others have made the same comment. I ad a nice note on it from Robert Littell.
I see Marco occasionally. He has plucked up quite a bit and is his old self. We remember you -- and take another drink His Hell Book like my stuff, apparently is waiting for someone to realize what a work of art is is -- and grab it off.
Laelah is still living with Jack Jones-running his print shop. Occasionally she intimates that married life is not what it was cracked up to be. Jack's got her working. Jack says you've forgotten him.
Don Wright was in for a few minutes this last week. He's with Ayer agency in Philadelphia. Still as enthusiastic as ever about writing. Seems to be making a real effort on his novel "Steam Whistle."
I am writing you care Boni & Liveright because I do not know where else to address you. Have you gone to the West Va farm? When are you likely to be out this way again. Ive become such a hermit crab -- stealing every hour I can for the novel -- that I dont see anybody. who can give me a real kick in the pants.
Affectionately
George
June 16/26
Completed

Dear Sherwood:
Marco was much interested in the reference to Earl Anderson in one of your recent letters. I told him about it while we were canvassing the old days, in a little rest at the Chicago Beach. He remembers Earl much better than I. Said he tried copy work at Critchfields before I came to Chicago I think I only met him once or twice. Marco called me up for your address yesterday, so I supposed you have a letter from him. I hope Earl has recovered.
I had lunch at the Dill Pickle with Laelah a few days ago. Apparently life is not going so well with her. She is much downcast over her failure to become pregnant. She had an operation last winter that she fears makes a child impossible . . . There's a passion for a child! She'd go through anything for one. I suspect she is right about the operation. I told her that she hadnt made assurance doubly sure. She should try fertilization from a younger source.
She seems to fit into the Dill Pickle life -- but her job in charge of Jacks print-shop is discouraging. What a story!
Your remarks about carrying a man across the Niagara well illustrate my experience -- also your comment on undertaking a novel about a woman. Ive learned some
Completed

2
things since I began Eve Watson. One thing I'm more certain of: The women I know-suburban bourgeoisie, Dill Pickle-women, artist, business women, are basically motivated by the same instincts, to a far more pronounced degree than men. That is the difference among women is more largely a matter of externals or accident My typist says they are far more simple than I think -- but she didn't know what I thought. I am a little chary of hard and fast conclusions.
The story gets on. The form has certainly tightened in this third attempt. Ill feel better about offering it this fall or winter.
Cornelia read the story of the old Minneapolis druggist and got a kick out of it. The pundits in the East that have examined it criticized it mainly on the score that it is "not a novel." I think the title is against it. "Some Men Write Fairy Stories" sounds like a collection of pipe dreams -- and of course it is largely that But it is a unified story. I think Ill call it "Ves Walmsley is Crazy"
Affectionately
George
Aug 17, 1926
Completed

Dear Sherwood:
"Eve Watson" is within ten to twelve thousand words of the finish, which at the rate I get to write will require four to five weeks. The story while not entirely up to the mark I aimed at is so close that I have a sense of scoring far better than in any previous work. There has been a feeling of the characters growing naturally -- developing themselves. You know what I mean -- and that is satisfying.
One thing is certain -- the criticism that runs against my previous stories, that is that they drag, or skirt the point, does not hold in this case. In fact the story has gone so fast that I may have to put a check-rein on it. I might almost say that this vital lovable Eve has almost gotten out of hand at one point and another.
Some Men Write Fairy Stories (my second) is still in N.Y. -- in the hands of The McWilliams Manuscript Service 112 W 42nd St. It sort of drifted into their hands last summer, and lay there weeks before
Completed

2
I located it. It has been read by Miss Elizabeth Otis, and Miss Mavis McIntosh. Know anything about these people?
I have had an intelligent criticism from Miss McIntosh who offers to try it on the market as it is but suggests that I cut it and do some other things. I have asked her for more definite specifications. Of course I don't intend to let every reader tell me what to do -- but as I get on, I can see past defects -- and some of her remarks hit home.
Marco's in town: He has told me about your foreward to Stephen Crane. I wish I'd gotten deeper into Crane at the time you speak of. Ill probably get back to him.

                                                     ------------------------------

God Im a naive Indian! Some close observation in ultra-sophistication this summer and fall have reminded me that I'm still a puritan in some old forgotten fibre. I am not altogether certain as to where naturalness ends and filth begins. Id like to talk some things over with you. 
I got The Time of Man and read it. Found it absorbing. That's good clean writing.
Affectionately
George
Oct 19, 26
Completed

Dear Sherwood
Im grabbing off a minute from this damned rush to write a few notes Ive had on my mind since your last letter. I hope you escaped the K.K. without any disastrous consequences.
"Another Man's House" promises much from your pen. I'm looking forward to it I get your point about a theme. In my hermit crab existence it is the one thing that makes life worth living -- but boy! -- any one that is capable of having a theme, and has a theme, has a most joyous life
Have had a charming session with old Marco. We agreed that if it is humanly possible, you and he and I shall get together for a session around a quart of scotch when you come this way. If Marco is in Chicago we will have it here; if not I will go to
Completed

2
Kansas City with you and we will meet Marco there -- or in Topeka. How does that strike you?
Don has gone to the Mitchell-Faust agency. He's going to save his money to go to Hamburg, or Mexico and write. He's been going round in circles about the girl. This week it looks as if it were all off. Lovable lad torn between his bourgeois instincts and his artist's soul.
Ive come to a little more light since I saw you. I am more than ever in the grip of feeling for the thing behind appearances. That no doubt seems to you like the primer of the artist -- but to realize it -- and to reach for it -- these are great experiences for me. And I've had some experiences. 
Don tells me he has written you to autograph a copy of The Story Teller's Story for me. (which he was to include in his check) It is for Papa Steele. If
Completed

3
havent already sent it, make it personal to him, some little line. 
Papa Steele sighs for you. Damit, your spell hangs over the advertising today. I was in Owensboro last week. He dragged out four of your old trade paper layouts and copy and instructed me to put them through. "Not" he was careful to explain "that you can not do them as well, but Anderson's headline "Goodbye Gloom and Loss" is just the thing for today."
Wishing you all the joys of this merry merry season, and looking forward to your coming
Affectionately
George
Completed

Thursday
Dear Sherwood: 
You probably have received the main facts as newspaper reported, and gossiped about the Y.K Smith-Wanda Stopa case. How the fiery young Polish woman lawyer in love with Y.K. went gunning for Mrs Smith at Palos Park and killed an old caretaker who got in the way. How she escaped the police here, and committed suicide by taking poison in Detroit after she was recognized.
It has been a first page sensation for several days. Poor old Y.K. has been interviewed and photographed until his sweet shy soul must be thoroly miserable. There has been much hurrying to and fro among their friends. It was hardly safe to admit that one knew the Smiths. The police and newspapers put on one of their most barbaric exhibitions of the invasion of privacy, in which our American guardians of morality, and our publicists excel. Rooms were broken into bureaus rifled for letters and photographs men and women followed and spied on, and detained (Tennis and Lucy Calhoun were met at Lucy's room by a tough detective and "quizzed" one night) Don Wright has been throwing
Completed

2
flip-flops. Confidentially, I think he enjoyed the thrills of hide and seek. A certain "Don" figured in the diary but they did not get our Don. At least his name was not printed in full in the reports.
Our "near north side candle lighted gin-soaked little bohemia" as Genevieve Forbes and other hell hounds of the Chicago newspapers like to term their fiction, has come in for a panning. I saw Genevieve at a distinctly bourgeois rum party a few weeks ago. It was more deeply rum soaked party than any I ever met in "the near north side bohemia"
The Smith-Stopa case is a sordid business -- but an insane girl like Wanda can work up just such little dramas. Incidentally what do you think now of the insanity of Wanda Tanska in my story "The Hiding Place? Rather justified wasnt it? However I took your comment to heart and re-wrote the last third of the story. You never had an opportunity to read that. Im getting back to writing -- or rather I'm figuring out how I can get to it at once. Lord -- but I'd love to have another hiding place like 735 North Cass or my room with the French family
Completed

3
on the west side! Don is moving into new apartments, and has invited me to avail myself I have hopes. It simply is not in the cards that I can follow agency routine and work on stories at home. I am thinking of taking a leaf from your old practice at Critchfield's and coming down to the office at the ungodly hour of 7 am!
I am glad for you, that the path is opening up again for a reasonably undisturbed pursuit of your writing Go - to - it!
I would love to meet you some time if even for a brief re-hash of our section of the problems of the universe. Morrow comes to town occasionally -- but he is bound round more tightly by the web of business than I am.
Don has drafted the layout of a novel on a one-armed fiddler that promises well. If he'd settle down to a good hard conscientious grind he'd do something.
Affectionately
George.
Completed

Dear Sherwood:
I have just returned from George McClellan's funeral which took me away several days. He was killed in an automobile accident at St. Joseph Mo where he published a paper. The body was taken to Springfield Ohio for burial I accompanied the funeral part and helped attend to arrangements. He was my brother in law. You doubtless remember "Mack" -- a charming man. You and Marco and I have been in parties with him.
"A Story Teller's Story" has arrived and I have read it kiver to kiver. The best interpretation of Sherwood that has yet appeared. -- a fascinating book, every chapter. I am rejoiced to hear that it is going over, and I think.
Completed

2
it will go over big
Have had a little opportunity to pick up my second story and it is running along interestingly -- to me. I haven't heard you say anything about the first section of this story, carbon of which you have. If you ever get time give it a little once over, and tell me what you think. The character of Ves Walmsley has become very real to me. I can spend hours with him in his spiritual orgies. 
I hear now and then that you will be in Chicago some time for an address or lecture to various organizations. Hope it is true.
Affectionately
George
Completed

Monday
Dear Sherwood:
You must have drawn a long sign of relief when that chapter was closed. I can realize how it must have sat on your chest like a leaden weight. Now that it is disposed of you'll get back to your writing with your old spirit. I'm rejoicing with you. Wish you were here. We'd open up a bottle.
I haven't seen T since the news broke in Chicago. It was covered in dispatches to the several papers. Hansen in the book page of the News said the reason was T's preference for city apartments as against suburban residences!
Don Wright is trying to choose between God and Mammon, or Christ and Apollo, tonight. He has had an offer to go with a big agency at a big salary at a job that will take all his tiem, and take all the sap out of him.
Much talk about the course you took -- and poor Don is wondering whether he is equal to it. I told him
Completed

2
plainly that he would have to make up his mind here and now to follow his art, or desert it entirely if he went in for a big cleanup on advertising. You see he is lured by the old will-o the wisp of piling up enough money to live two or three years in Germany or France -- and then to go back to his writing. God -- what I'd give to be 32 and unmarried as he is! It wouldn't take me long to choose.
I think Ill get back to my second story soon. It couldnt be done in the publication business. But this place makes one think of the old Critchfield where such things could be done.
Another thing I told Don is that if one lays off too long -- until conditions are right -- the vision fades. One pays and pays for being a recreant. I know.
Morrow and I attended a party given by Margie Curry at her apartments two weeks ago. Both of us were piped. Morrow had a good time. Made one after another listen to him -- but
Completed

3
I was sober enough to get the picture.
You see Margie has become quite respectable. As a consequence it was a mixed company Very respectables, and a sprinkling of free spirits. A chafing restraint. Margie palpably nervous. I missed the old joy of intermingling pure reason, anarchy and damfoolishness that used to make her parties so good.
Will get the Rosenfeld book. Have just finished Huysmann's La Bas (Down There) A hairlifting book on Satanism of the middle ages and present. Have you seen it? Odd -- the things the censors have suppressed are child's play compared to this. Yet the artist subordinates the horrors to his art and maintains a philosophic dignity throughout
Well -- here's for everything this new chapter means to you. Nothing I could think of would give me the thrill of shaking your hand right now -- unless it should be a gift from the high gods of an hermitage of my own. My felicitations to Elizabeth, and the keen anticipation of a meeting some day
With Love
George
Completed

Tuesday midnight
Dear Sherwood:
Just left Hanly Bohon in the dazed state of one on awaking after he has passed away on bootleg liquor. Im not so damned sober myself.
Hanly left the Congress in the care of a lady friend that seemed to know him. He had sent for her and she called him "Hanly." She was a good looker and seemed to be trustworthy. Said she would take Hanly to his train. I hope she did. He was in a hell of an irritable state and didnt want the company of anyone else.
Hanly reached me on the phone
Completed

after getting our phone girls all stirred up by his language when the asked me who my friend was after I came in, I couldn't guess
But I found him at the Congress with a bootlegger who had more liquor than I've seen in one grip since prohibition. They had corraled the damdest dumb bell of a courtesan I ever met. Wouldn't take her hat and coat off -- wouldnt talk -- had nothing for sale except her skinny body. Hanly was roaring for a party. I got in touch with an art studio, and soon we had more girls than we needed. Six I think and for three men. A girl for or a
Completed

woman of about 38 from France took charge of Hanly and attended him tenderly as he went to sleep. She had much more intelligence than most of the others. Rather appealing sympathy. A protege of hers was a young American hard boiled. I told her she was wasting time on me -- and she thanked me for the information and promptly began work elsewhere.
The French woman made a drive on me at the last. The old crude practices of the profession The tongue kiss - - - ear lapping God! It has been a long time. I revolted and pulled out of the party. I thought I was pretty well seasoned - - Odd how old instincts rise in disgust
Completed

Our bourgeois business men take their pleasure sadly. Hanly got sore on the so kindly French woman, and poured out the most indecent contempt I have ever heard addressed to a female. Silence fell on the company. She took it calmly however, and insisted that Hanly was a good boy. (I think she had done business with him in the bathroom)
"Horses and Men" lay on the dresser top among the bottles. Hanly had evidently tried to read it. Don Wright has come to work with Porter Eastman Byrne.
I haven't seen T since I wrote you. Been turning flip flops in the noble profession
Life is horrible
Affectionately
George
Completed

Dear Sherwood:
Do you remember a theme for a book that I laid before you and Waldo Frank one day at lunch -- "This Is Hell" -- in which I would undertake to prove that we are now in the place of punishment for damned souls? This Earth is the spot, and life is the punishment. We are kept busy dodging the big fiends and the little fiends -- and occasionally they get us and put us to the torture. The idea rather interested Frank. Well anyway --
I could have written a stirring chapter of that book last night. Just imagine this:
One of our Chicago clients called up and asked us to insert a little paragraph in an ad. I went to his office with the revision and had just about got it worded to his satisfaction when Old Man Porter came in. This was one of Porter's clients. He amiably kicked the revision into the
Completed

2
discard and said the whole ad should be re-written. Then by way of getting material he said he and I would spend the rest of the afternoon visiting retailers and getting their story.
Thats all run-of-mine stuff but -- I had to stay with the old cuss for dinner, and until 10:30 p.m. talking about that ad and revising it with him. He spent half an hour trying to decide whether we would use the word "desired" or "desirable." Another long period on "think" or consider. We made as many as six re-writings of one paragraph. -- and at the end of those three agonizing hours we had made just three little changes in the wording
My God man! Im a sinner -- no doubt I committed some unspeakable crime in a past existence. But dont you think Goddlemighty overdoes the thing in punishing sinners
Completed

3
sometimes? Can you imagine being closeted three to four hours with Charlie Parker on any subject! The "torture" was eased very little today when I had to go into "conference" with Forrest Crissey the industrial writer of the Saturday Evening Pest!
So much for moiling at the gold mill -- Your letter indicates that the long wait for the close of the present chapter of your story is almost over. It must be a relief. Also I "heard you the first time" about vacation plans. I sure do hope we can get together somewhere. It would be like a shower in a drouth to me. 
I saw T at the Gurdjieff Dancers a few evenings ago -- a company of French dancers with something unfamiliar in the way of their art. The school lives in seclusion at Fontainbleau, where it acquires some unusual accomplishments in training the mind to operate independently of the body. T was with Aldis whose wife was in the East. T who is one of the patrons of the Dancers' appearance here, looked well. It was said lately
Completed

4
that she was going to New York account Oneals theatrical business I hear that Oneal has had another run of hard luck and the venture is closed for the present. At any rate T has not gone.
Morrow will be in at the end of the week. We will get a bottle or two of hootch and settle some more problems of the universe
Completed

R.H.
RUDD HOUSE 
OWENSBORO, KY.
OTHO FOWLER, MANAGER.
Thursday
Dear Sherwood:
"How's Anderson? Ever hear of him? Asked Papa Steele at the end of a long day's grind of circulars letters etc (Jesus! It has been a hot day)
And when I told him that I had seen you lately he said "I would have made a trip to Chicago to meet him again"
I never heard the old boy speak so affectionately of anyone else. He is proud of the fact that he has so much of your "literature" (adv. literature) around. Treasures it. Thats about all of your literature that he has read. I told him about yours
Completed

R.H.
RUDD HOUSE 
OWENSBORO, KY.
OTHO FOWLER, MANAGER.
of the July Century and he noted it to look it up. Also I promised to send him March Dial with Robert Morse Lovett's review of "Horses & Men"
Ive got an evening off and here I am in my B.V.Ds getting ready to finish a chapter of my second story before midnight. So Au revoir. The story calls
With Love
George
Completed

Dear Sherwood:
I envy you down there in a retreat that satisfies you -- where things are favorable to thinking, and writing. Go to it boy! You are now a position to turn out the read stuff, after the drought of waiting. Dont let my stuff bother you. -- but I shall be glad of your judgment, now that the first yarn has got cold. Don has been reading it lately. Looking over his shoulder I can see many spots that would be changed -- or cut out -- were I doing it over.
Your visit was a real help Damit! I needed your philosophy of the love of life as opposed to the love of death. I have been training too much with the gloomy one. Im definitely off the gloom now. As a result I have been doing some plugging on the second story since you left.
Marco was in town the Sunday that you left. We both tore out the telephones trying to find you -- at the Schevell's at the hotel, and at the station. I told Morrow you'd be back here probably in the fall for a lecture. Let me know far enough in advance if possible to get him here. He comes from Topeka frequently. It will be worth while to split a bottle and settle the problems of life again with him. Old
Completed

2
Morrow is in the midst of the loveliest chapter of all his loves. He is in truth to be envied. A dozen men are in love with her. -- but they are friends of Morrow and so -- You would like her.
Let me know how things go with you when you get settled with Elizabeth and Bob. Also dont forget the organization of cotton men. It ought not to be hard to make a darn good excuse for me to come to New Orleans.
I notice that a letter from you to Don has just arrived. He isnt in yet 9:30 a.m. Advertising business certainly sits lightly on his chest. Wish I were more like that.
With love
George
Completed

Dear Sherwood:
I had lunch and a delightful two hours with Cornelia last Saturday. She is at the University of Chicago on a course in Latin. Looks fine and is fine. She certainly is doing a corking thorough job in teaching. Every time I see her I mavel at the facility with which she picks up the hardest stuff.
She told me about the boys. By this time I judge they are with you. Growing up eh. Well they're as interesting a pair of kids as I ever met -- and I'll bet their lives will be worth while. Mimi, I understand is at Pt. Sable. I asked Cornelia whether Mimi would be a careerist. Cornelia isn't certain. There are evidences of strength and individuality with possibilities. One thing I'm certain of -- she'll be a heart-breaker. Also that she is a chip off the old block -- (Anderson side) Ive become pretty much an old hermit-crab spending nearly all my spare time alone with my yarn. It is spinning along at a rate that will enable me to have it ready to enter in the Atlantic Monthly's contest next winter. I am going to enter it. That may ensure it a reading anyhow. Im sort of
Completed

2
worried about my Minneapolist Druggist novel -- "Some Men Write Fairy Stories." After Macmillan's turned it down, Herman Schuchert suggested that he could reach Edna Kenton of Brand & Brand through a friend of his Sherman A Manchester with the Western Union Life Insurance Co, 50 East 42nd St. N.Y. I had the manuscript delivered to him in April and he hasnt vouchsafed a word. Herman has written and wired him -- but never an answer do we get. It cost about $75 to get that typed. I have the carbon (or Cornelia has) but I dont like to send that out.
I didn't make out the name of your farm Write it again. I sure wish I were there I'll be the weather is better than July in Chicago.
Affectionately
George.
Completed

Feb 9
Dear Sherwood:
The second novel is finished -- typed -- bound in a ring-book -- ready to go out as soon as I have had a few pages re-typed for neatness.
It is called "Some Men Write Fairy Stories." It is a better job than I had really anticipated. Three and a half years I have been occupied with this at odd hours I could steal from business and Sundays and holidays.
You will understand, I know, the feeling of regret with which I wrote the closing words. I have lived with old Ves Walmsley these three and a half years -- and it is like saying goodbye to an old friend.
Now I want a new theme. I shall feel lost until I find character studies under circumstances that I think I can handle -- another family as it were. I haven't the slightest idea who they are -- but I think a Woman will be the central figure. I have never done a story around a Woman -- not since I began the second story have I looked at the first -- until this week. I realize keenly the truth of your comment that there are holes in it. Certainly I had a surer grip on the
Completed

2
second tale.
I want you to read "Some Men Write Fairy Stories" -- at your convenience. Im going ahead to market it, and I hope your readings of it will be in the printed volume. So much I owe to your brotherly interest, and the good talks we had about it in New Orleans that I feel it will hold you to the end.
Marco told me about the calamity the burning of your mss. at Boni & Liveright's. Marco said it was the original in long hand. No carbon! Jesus! Thats awful! You and Carlisle have something in common now. "The French Revolution" in long hand of course -- only copy was burned, and he had to drive two hard years on the re-writing.
I've seen Don twice at lunch. He's settling down to married life -- painting and furnishing his new home and all that. Scared skittish by the fear that conventional married life will get him. Issues a Declaration of Independence every time he refers to it. Says he's working on the great novel. Has enough money to run him for three or four months. Says he is going to Parish in June. He certainly is a study
Affectionately   George
Completed

Mar 29
Dear Sherwood:
Elizabeth Steele died last Thursday (Mar 25) of pneumonia. So ends the life of a beautiful high-spirited girl who laughed as she put up a long battle against tremendous odds. The body was created at Graceland. It is hard to realize that all physical that remains of so vivid a personality, is a few handsful of ashes. Her mother is left alone, at an advanced age. Elizabeth worked at Lord & Thomas agency up to the time she went to hospital 12 days before her death. Her little estate will probably take care of her mother.
Life runs on. I have a note from Macmillan's this morning, acknowledging receipt of my novel -- the second one of which you have read a part -- and promising Mr. Robert Littell's attention. Just as soon as I can pull myself together I shall begin another. It will deal with Woman -- which of course means a conflict with Man. The theme will be the warfare of woman's instinct with man's logic. Doesnt sound very original stated thus, but I feel that
Completed

2
I have some slants that I can use in spinning a yarn.
I see mention of your notebook in the N.Y. Times Review. Is the book out?
Laelah Cooper married Jack Jones of the Dill Pickle about two weeks ago. An odd alliance. Laelah still retains her connection with this agency -- and there is nervousness over this open introduction of radicalism into our so capitalistic business -- the introduction being symbolized by Jack's appearance at our offices with Laelah every day or so, in his blue hickory shirt open at the neck, his truck driving corduroys, and gunmans cap atop his shock of hair. Jack has mellowed however and gives indications settling down into the life of a bourgeois printer with his toys Doodill ducks as another line. The Dill Pickle still settles questions of the universe.
Don Wright has gone to the Ayer Agency Philadelpha. -- Dons savings having vanished Don has high hopes of getting backing for that grand opera work of his
Marco is quite cheered up by Laelah's marriage
Affectionately   George
Completed

Friday 
Dear Sherwood:
What I think most appeals to you, is the fact of my writing that novel rather than the novel itself. Therein, to you, is the story.
I know it is full of holes -- lousy with defects from an artistic point of view as you say; but you know I did not do it primarily as a work of art but as a release -- just as I write on the second book today -- when I get a chance.
Not that I want to hide behind that excuse -- or make it an easy escape from criticism of its defects. Also I should be ashamed of a cheap satisfying pride that I had "done something" Never claimed that. 
You remember that after you and I went over it at Julius's just before you started east, I went back and re-wrote about a third of it -- unraveling the story naturally, as you suggested. I rather the second handling, but Morrow took issue with it. He thought the first handling more logical. So did Don, who instanced the Wanda Stopa case in point.
But Sherwood -- the thing I prize most is -- whatever there is in that work that causes you to
Completed

2
to go back to it. Your criticism is the only influence that has led me to make any important change.
What you say about your advantage in years as an artist is obviously true. You know how I feel about that. But I know there is something finer between us than the relation of you as an artist, and myself as the artist you think I might be. You did throw off the life of fact more boldly, and take great chances than I. The sense of your superiority that I feel in this, is only the sense of honest joy in the triumphs of my friend.
As for the struggle -- the lines of Heine come to me

      "We do not take possession of our ideas
        They take possession of us
        They force us into the arena
        And compel us to fight them."

It is difficult for me to write of the struggle and myself. God knows I have a holy horror of posing as a martyr! Yet I have been defeated -- so far. For me, the issue is clearly drawn. Either I stay where I am, or make a complete getaway. When I came up to Ephraim to see you, I had intended to submerge completely. Once I walked back and forth in front of the labor agencies on Canal street, trying to get up courage to enroll with a lumber gang for the North Woods as time-keeper. Defeated by the second thought. "There ought to be a way out of this without sacrificing everything" And
Completed

3
there have been other times - - -
I know that it is your affection that brings you back to the determination that I shall become an artist I know that the things that block and baffle me do not seem insurmountable to you. The Moment may come when they shall not seem so to me. But facing the music in the way you suggest is not the answer. There are things to be done -- after which that would be comparatively easy. You think it would be for the good of my soul. I dont want to beg the question -- but why would the name on the cover or fly-leaf be important? If the novel is lousy and full of holes, it is because I am lousy and full of holes. By whose standard? The critics? Dont misunderstand me. I have a profound respect for the judgment of some of them. But must I proclaim myself an artist?
So far I have written as I felt, and polished as my sense or feeling for what I was trying to say dictated. . .  I haven't read the thing for along while (being enthusiastically absorbed in the second story) but I have no doubt I would throw out lots of it on a careful re-reading. One gets to a finer feeling, and a better sense of proportion with the years. 
Write me on this point: What is the thing that should induce an artist to reconstruct a work -- beyond his own feeling, and that of his friend who comes with understanding into the innermost and sacred rooms of his house of life. One does not
Completed

4
analyze one's feeling for a friend -- but certainly one of the great things in you that I respect is your detachment from the influences that clutch at the artist on every side. You told 'em to go to hell, because in addition to what you did not know you would not be burdened with what they did not know. 
But about the novel: You take it -- all of it -- treat the manuscript as if it were your own -- save or throw out where you think best -- use the thought or phrase of it -- add or subtract at any point. If it ever gets to a publisher, let it be as your own, over your own name. You have as great strong a claim to it as I -- and it may be as I think that the novel is in the fact of my writing it. I will it to you on condition that you keep my name out of it.
Meanwhile I shall go on with the second story -- writing for release -- disciplining my imagination as it certainly needs to keep it clean -- unhampered by mechanics (but the second story is certainly a better job)
Again my repugnance to cant; but I really do not see the importance of the artist's name. There is good precedent. The Book of Job for one -- a rather apt illustration in my case. 
Write me -- and if you think I need another drubbing -- well -- you know how to administer it
Affectionately 
George
Completed

Sunday 
Dear Sherwood:
"God!" you said once "How life makes one pay and pay when one begins to compromise!"
"Well -- not to wait, but to laugh -- you were right. You're dam right, you're right! It is as the Life said You took that trouncing -- eh! Lets see how much more you will stand.
All of which is my main reflection after crawling out of the damdest grilling I ever had.
The agency can pile it on a-plenty as you know -- but that's nothing. The girl that runs Marco's Household magazine collapsed and threw the job of summarizing a big market survey onto me. Can you imagine it. Statistics on soap, oil stores breakfast foods and the like that kept me grinding past midnight -- nights on end.
That's why I haven't answered your good letters more promptly. Dog tired -- not a thought worth setting down
Completed

2
Except one chuckle! I did write about 10000 words more of my second story in the last three months. Good stuff a whimsical things with a real undertone I wish I might read it to you when we get together. And I'll have time to do 10000 more this fall. I have read and re-read the plan you sent me about a month ago -- (not a plan but your own concept of your characters) It is as clear an exposition as can be made of what your friends understand -- but I wouldn't put it in the book. Those that "get" you get that in some sort -- and that is a big element of the power -- and the Uneasy Question that puzzles those that dont get it
Old Don is plugging away -- writing reams of novels, all in that nervous undigesting way of his. Like his music Something to it if he would settle down and go deep. Have you ever looked over his manuscripts? Some real diamonds here and there. Better in poetry than prose
Poor old Don is running around in circles, as the result of what you and I have said to him, and the
Completed

3
plumb crazy over his girl. Thinks now he will drop everything and come to New Orleans to see you. Girl says to go by all means -- stay a year. That makes him crazier than ever. Ill hand it to the girl She knows the game by instinct
Had lunch with Cornelia yesterday She's looking fine. Cheerful stoic. John and Marion doing well in school. She tells me that Robert should be in Bremen by now
I don't know whether T has returned or not. Must look her up. Ive been a regular hermit on this job
Oh - heres an echo of the noble profession that will give you a smile. Pa Hart and Ray Woltz both thrown out of Critchfield by Scott Smith and a newcomer named Salisbury who have gained control of the agency. Also your old friend Chauncy Hill is out. He's the lad that undertook
Completed

4
to teach you 100% Americanism during the war. I know you'll shed tears. Seems he got unpleasant over Salisbury's expense accounts soon after Salisbury came in. when S became one of the bosses one of the first things he remembered to do was to disconnect Chauncy from his job.
Hope you get to "Beggars on Horseback" now running here Splendid satire on Don and me and our like. A dream play. Artist penned up in cages by Big Business. Only has to shake the bars -- door opens and artist walks out. Hell I've shaken the bars several times -- but theres something wrong with the dam catch
Affectionately
George
Completed

Wednesday
Dear old Sherwoodio:
Let's dont be embarassed by any fear that we get each other wrong. The only way in which you could hurt my feelings would be to kick me out and turn your back -- and even then I should hope that I had got you wrong. 
It would be fun to be the joint author of a book with you -- but My name on that book, under the present circumstances would raise hell.
And perhaps I exaggerate that. I am moved to this suspicion by my irritation over a really excellent book that I am now reading "Isles of Illusion" edited by Bohun Lynch (Small Maynard & Co Boston) in which he conceals the name of the real author under the name "Asterisk." Why should Asterisk go to such trouble to conceal his identity from me? What egotism! And even under incognito the Editor declines to print a letter from Asterisk giving the particulars of his taking a South Sea Islander as "his woman."
Completed

2
At any rate I should like nothing better than to talk over your ideas regarding the novel -- and we will do so at the first opportunity which I hope will come soon
Affectionately
George
Completed

Dear Sherwoodio
Take your time about my stories. They had been lying in my desk rarely disturbed for two years until you came. That is, the first one had. I worked on the second one whenever I could get an opportunity; but I had to grab off opportunities under difficulties after I left the place I had so beautifully arranged for writing. In other words when I resumed work for a living. Your visit stirred me to renewed effort, I have been pulling one of your old stunts -- getting down to the office early and writing until the hum of business begins around me. Im having a lot of fun
Completed

with the second story. I shall be deeply interested in what you say about that when you get around to it. It has a foundation that gives me free scope for all the wierd crazy delightful adventures on which I wish to embark -- and I think it gets across, a worth-while idea. Dont misunderdstand. It has no complexes nor mission. It doesn't pretend to be other than what it is -- an absorbing release, in which plot is the very last thing. There isn't any.
Awfully glad to see in your letters that you are back at it with re-doubled enthusiasm. It must be a great job to bury yourself in it unworried by the things that have dragged at you for the last two years. Don
Completed

and I are looking forward to your next output. The advertising people that know you read with particular interest your sketch in the Century. It made more of an impression on them than anything else of yours that they have read. They could almost understand it. 
What a number of tales sit on the doorstep of the house of my mind! - - - The shadow of the father confessor follows me around. Lately I have heard a confession regarding a man past 50 that I thought pickled in cynicism. A young girl has galvanized him into the passion of jealousy that belongs to the twenties. I have heard the confession
Completed

of a young girl who was crying because she had wrought upon a young male puritan by sex radiation until he suffered the torture of an orgasm lying by her side -- and then did penance by extolling the virtues of "the other girl" to whom he was engaged.
A young artist is running around in a circle alternately attracted by an irresistible passion and repelled by a closeup view of a pit of frightful jealousy. I am a helpless man 

                                             ------------------------------

My regards to Robert. I look for something fine from that boy.
With Love
George.
Completed

Tuesday
Dear Sherwood:                                                    Tennessee
Your request for Don Wright's address served to revive our friendship (Wrights and mine) and we have had a few drinks together, to your health. T and Wright and I went to the apartment of a very interesting young woman that I think you have not met -- Laelah Cooper advertising manager of Household. T fell in love with Laelah, and Laelah reciprocates her affection. We have had tea at T's studio.
Marco came to town last week, and T. Laelah Marco and I had dinner together. T read a letter on art and artists that she had written to someone not named. It is unusual -- a fresh viewpoint -- and made an impression. We all urged her to make an essay of it and send it to Mercury. It deals with the reflex of external conditions on the artist, and his attempt to establish a balance. Rather authentic in its psychology. An imperative against the soul sickness of the period.
I have another indefinite lunch engagement with Don. Will try to pick up what I can about with Don. Will try to pick up what I can about things of yours that he has -- though it may take a little time so as not to roil the waters.
I do not think you need have any fear on this score. T is much more her old self apparently, than she was even a year ago. She seems to have recovered her poise -- her quiet jollity, and her whimsical cynicism. She has done a lot more figures in clay -- one
Completed

2
a lovely full length womans figure, nude and sitting. A portrait bust of Aldis has been done in bronze These things with her essay on art and artists show that she has been fairly industrious. Morrow gave the dinner for us four in his room at the Great Northern. -- and of course it was complete. He really had the confidential visit with T that he has so long planned.
Don has developed a complex that will give you a smile. He lives in the basement under T at 153 East Erie St. --where Herman and Betty used to live. A cosy cubby hole, in which he ought to be as happy as a prince. But -- listen -- and likewise wow! A family of negroes lives in the same basement! You wouldnt think that would worry Don the revolutionary -- bit it does. "Suppose" he said to Helen Dupre' "I should want to give a reception!" Don threatened to move out, but I understand the negroes are going, and if so, peace will be restored. You never can tell. The old things in the fibre, set up astonishing cross currents even in anarchists I suppose.
I have been something more than an innocent by-stander while a hell of a case has been going on. A little dancer of 21 blew into Chicago last April, in the family way. She had an affair with a young college professor in one of the towns of the tall grass. Came to Chicago to
Completed

3
have an abortion but was scared out when the doctor to whom she was recommended refused to do it. She had about $1.09 in her purse when looking for a girl she knew, she went to the apartment of a young business woman who took her in. The young business woman had responsibilities of her own that took every cent she was making -- but she took in the sister in trouble -- tho she had never seen her before. She has kept her through the pregnancy, housed and clothed her, and paid a considerable share of the expenses.
I am one of three friends of the business woman in Chicago that know. We cheered her along up to the time for the little dancer to go to the hospital. Then we began to get worried about finances The perspective daddy wasn't coming through. $300 was finally extracted from him to pay the bills -- and now the little dancer is back on the business woman's hands with the baby. It looks this afternoon as if the dancer and her 3 weeks old boy will be safely stowed with a family -- with enough of the $3000 left to get on for a few weeks -- when she will have to get a job. She refuses to part with the baby, and she refuses to let her family in on the secret. The funny part is that the business woman who is "broke" and we three who have stood by her have held hours of conference and
Completed

have sweated blood, while the youthful daddy and mammy have blithely gone ahead as tho it was the world's business to take care of penniless people who are indiscreet enough to get caught. Both the girl and her lover are radicals I got a rise out of T by telling her that when the social revolution comes we bourgeoisie will have to finance it.
Much business of making another change. Next Monday I go to work for [new address. -->]Porter Eastman Byrne Co 22 West Monroe St. You know -- the agency formed by Charlie Porter and Charlie Byrne. Doing a pretty good business -- and I'll get $7500. Expect to take the Kentucky accounts with me. It's my old game -- and I'll probably have more time there than I have in this selling business where the hard-boileds can run rings around me. Morrow sorry to let me go. Capper's landing on him about expenses. I made the break myself to help him out. Says he will get me back at the first opportunity.
Wish I were with you and that 3 gals of hootch. Morrow says your work in Mercury is great stuff. Im going out to get a copy.
Affectionately           Daugherty
Completed

Friday 
Dear Sherwood:
I lunched with Don Wright today, and in the course of discussion of you and your writing, I asked him if he had anything of yours. I said that you were looking up some of your scattered impedimenta and had asked me if I had anything.
He said he had nothing of yours -- that T had let him have the bed he is using in the basement at 153 East Erie.
So that's what I think T meant by things she had given him -- possibly some other articles to furnish his room. Ive been there but did not notice. If you have anything in particular in mind, Ill see the next time I go over to drink Wrights gin.
A damned stupid week. Not off with the old -- not on with the new -- and pull-hauled from both sides. I wrapped up my stories to move 'em again. May be able to get back to em again, after I get squared away at the old copy-writing. This selling game is far too strenuous for art. They dont leave one much time to do anything but sell. It is moiling at the gold-mill all right. Well its something to have dreams anyway. More later. Dont forget at Porter Eastman Byrne Co, 22 West Monroe St
Affectionately  Daugherty
Completed

Thursday 
Dear Sherwood
I met Pa Hart this morning. I said "Have you done anything in that matter of Sherwood Anderson I took up with you?"
He said: "I did so"
Which I take to mean that he has sent the long delayed "commish." Advise me -- as this has been on my mind. I trust you have your check by this time. 
I hear indirectly that T is going to the country (in N.Y state) for a rest after her work with the Negro Players. Her address will be care of Ernestine Evans Pomona, Rockland County New York until further notice (this news was of June 5)
T. is apparently in something like her old spirit. She's had a rather exciting time. At Boston things were going beautifully -- when the mayor put the kibosh on "Salome." From Boston the Players (broke) went to Broadway. They had two weeks there, and had more newspaper space than anything in town counting the hostile as well as the friendly notices.
Completed

2
The had, it was said, the most distinguished audiences of the season. But -- as T says -- it was a case of the higher the fewer, so they went to Philadelphia and played in a Negro theater. There the booking agent did them dirt -- tied up the box office receipts and tried to get the company away from O'Neil. That left the outfit stranded. T hustled around and raised $1000 in Philadelphia that partly paid salaries to the clamoring company, and they went back to New York to play a week at a Negro house. T. says "Its been hard work, but enthusiasm and excitement -- good tonics. It is only now that we are about through with the season and are facing the financial problem of getting them back to Chicago, that I realize how tired I am."
I am plugging away -- slowly -- on my second story. It has got me into a field where I have to cast about a bit. Ive got the psychology all right -- but I have to familiarize myself with the setting. 
There is not much to tell you. I'm playing a lone hand -- see very few outside the business grind, which as usual is quite too pestiferous. But Im having a very good time with myself -- and the story
Affectionately
George.
Completed

Wednesday --
Dear Sherwood:
I have finished "Dark Laughter" and have lent my copy to Lailah Cooper. It is hard for me to write what I think without becoming conscious. I can only say that I glowed with pride. You've done something -- I want to say finer than anything that has gone before, because of course in much, it is different. But as a whole it is finer. It discloses the poet, as well as the prose artist -- with clear direction through innermost and undefined recesses. 
That you knew the music of dark laughter I was certain -- but frankly -- and I may have said so to you -- I didn't think the Four Arts ball was in your line. I take it back whole heartedly. It is an interpretation that under your touch goes beyond -- a way beyond. I am still pondering the curious psychology in the revelation of Rose Frank. Another section that I shall re-read is that of the try-out of Aline by the artist's wife. 
After reading the book I should have thought what you said about Joyce (and Dark Laughter) even if you
Completed

2
had not written. It is worth something to me that I sensed what I did in Ulysses, before I had read a word of review. 
I have been reading Havelock Ellis's "Dance of Life." That too, has broadened my understanding of good writing I think. Ulysses, Dark Laughter and The Dance of Life have in some sort of released me from subservience to standards and technic, to which you know I have always -- in everything -- tended to my undoing What says holy scripture "The letter killeth -- the spirit quickeneth." 
I found it so in the story on which I am plodding along. From a purely poetical, or allegorical concept. I found myself dropping -- (my old trouble) -- into descriptive or photographic stuff, which as you would say a hundred men in American could do better. I was up against a stone wall -- until I saw the light again.
There is of course much talk about Dark Laughter here I suppose you have seen the reviews. Some growling over Harry Hansen's stepping out of his province  as a reviewer to allude to personal and
Completed

3
private matters that are none of his concern. Execrable taste!
I look forward to your coming and the long talk. Don I suppose is on his way by boat to N.O. -- if he hasn't arrived. Not much news of him. Mercury I hear has asked to examine more of his work. 
Lunched with Margie Curry this noon. She hears that Bob is back here. Whats the news about him. I'm writing Cornelia a line. Haven't seen her for along time
Affectionately
George
Completed

Friday 
Dear Sherwood:
Just delivered another chapter of Ves Walmsley to the typist -- met Herman Schuchert (Jeremy Lane now) and had two drinks and lunch with him. First time I had seen Herman since last winter. He had just sent manuscript of his ninth book to his agent. Only two have been published "Yellow Men Sleep" and one other: "Light Stuff" he says, I've never read any of his work. He still has great hopes of being published. Says he can't do anything serious -- and I do not think he can. But he pounds away -- four hours at the typewriter most every evening. Max Grove's had a hell of a time. Worked for a while on the night shift of a lumber factory at South Bend. His baby died suddenly last week, and he and Shirley are knocked out. Bill Hollingsworth's back in town -- married -- and is making money doing work for a commercial art studio. I saw Vaughn yesterday at lunch. He's working in
Completed

2
in an advertising agency. Max Wald is still in Europe. Expects to come back next winter. So much for the little children.
Morrow has written some good negro spirituels for his Hell Book and is having final typing done for publication Lailah is still working for us -- and hasn't altogether recovered from the blow.
I have your copy of "Ulysses" -- and I really have it. Conscience has hurt me about keeping it so long. Ill ship it back the day you say the word -- but Morrow wants to read it: Shall I turn it over to him. I read it through -- and got a great deal out of it when the big idea dawned on me. You know I went to sleep over it at your house 
By this time you have probably heard from Don. He writes me that he wrote you. Said he was going to New Orleans this month
Completed

3
What do you mean you are going to the country next summer? Just to get away from the hot weather -- or are you thinking of leaving New Orleans? Will be looking for you when you get on your lecture tour.
Cards advertising Dark Laughter are on the tables of the Walden book shop. That will be on sale I suppose in two weeks
Affectionately
George.
